title: rexquigg
author: rexquigg
created_time: December 29, 2022, 12:20:32 AMLast edit: December 29, 2022, 03:14:25 AM by rexquigg
content: Hello!We're excited to announce the launch of our new platform for monetizing online content. Our system allows users to easily create locked links that require payment in Bitcoin to unlock. This is a great way for content creators to earn revenue from their work and for users to access high-quality content.Here's how it works:Create a locked link at https://2see.ca and set the price for unlocking the content in BitcoinUsers can then share the locked link with others and receive direct payment when the content is unlockedOur platform is easy to use and provides a secure way for users to monetize their content and for others to access it. We hope you'll check it out and see the value it can bring to your content monetization efforts.Thank you for considering our service!

comments.author: Edwardard
comments.body: Hey, welcome to the forum! You might move this one to service announcement board since this is related to a service not project development imo.Have a bitcointalk ANN thread link on the website for redirecting ppl to open discussion.And my query is how safe is your site? Does it store the data of all the visitors?

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: Edwardard on December 29, 2022, 02:56:41 AMAnd my query is how safe is your site? Does it store the data of all the visitors?We don't collect information for any third party. The only information stored is that supplied when you create a link.Since the unlock address specified is your own, you don't need to trust us with your coins. The unlock process happens based on public blockchain data, and I believe this is the safest method possible for an unlock address.

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.created_time: December 29, 2022, 07:25:40 AMLast edit: December 29, 2022, 08:46:40 AM by LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: rexquigg on December 29, 2022, 03:22:52 AMSince the unlock address specified is your own, you don't need to trust us with your coins.Users still have to trust you show the correct unlock address, and not your own address. It could be used for an exit scam: once there are enough users, you could change all addresses for your own and cash in big one time.QuoteThe unlock process happens based on public blockchain data, and I believe this is the safest method possible for an unlock address.Is it intentional that only one user has to pay, after which the content gets unlocked for everyone who has the link?I tested it: https://2see.ca/l/TDp1qIZq-PFP0hAXKuJaY_wK, and the Bitcoin address I used received payments in the past already. The content was instantly unlocked.

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 07:25:40 AMUsers still have to trust you show the correct unlock address, and not your own address. It cuold be used for an exit scam: once there are enough users, you could change all addresses for your own and cash in big one time.I want to be as transparent and honest as possible. You are correct, users need to trust that we are not exit scamming them. Trust is a crucial factor in most businesses, and we are committed to building a sustainable and successful service for the long term.Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 07:25:40 AMIs it intentional that only one user has to pay, after which the content gets unlocked for everyone who has the link?I tested it: https://2see.ca/l/TDp1qIZq-PFP0hAXKuJaY_wK, and the Bitcoin address I used received payments in the past already. The content was instantly unlocked.Thank you for trying it out. Yes that is intentional. The link is unlocked for everyone who has it as soon as the address received amount is greater than or equal to the requested amount. Address reuse is considered dangerous, so a new address for each link is intended.

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: rexquigg on December 29, 2022, 08:21:14 AMThank you for trying it out. Yes that is intentional. The link is unlocked for everyone who has it as soon as the address received amount is greater than or equal to the requested amount.I can't help but think this won't work for the majority of uses. Say you're an Onlyfans creator, and say you want to have users pay for content. It makes much more sense to have each user pay 0.0002BTC to a unique address, instead of having them pay a certain amount collectively.QuoteAddress reuse is considered dangerous, so a new address for each link is intended.Address reuse isn't dangerous, it's bad for privacy. But you're still doing it: when I set a larger amount than the address has received, your site tells me to pay the difference between that amount and the amount already sent to the address.You could ask the user for their master public key, which allows you to generate different addresses for each link request. To avoid a large "gap" in between addresses, you could for instance start over after the first 100 unused addresses.

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 09:03:27 AMI can't help but think this won't work for the majority of uses. Say you're an Onlyfans creator, and say you want to have users pay for content. It makes much more sense to have each user pay 0.0002BTC to a unique address, instead of having them pay a certain amount collectively.The primary use case we have in mind is for a content creator one-on-one with a customer selling their completed work. It allows the simple flow from payment to the unlocking of content. That collective unlocking is possible is simply an interesting side-effect.Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 09:03:27 AMAddress reuse isn't dangerous, it's bad for privacy. But you're still doing it: when I set a larger amount than the address has received, your site tells me to pay the difference between that amount and the amount already sent to the address.You are right again. Partial payments are not really intended though.Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 09:03:27 AMYou could ask the user for their master public key, which allows you to generate different addresses for each link request. To avoid a large "gap" in between addresses, you could for instance start over after the first 100 unused addresses.Thanks for the suggestion. We will consider further how selling the same content repeatedly could work, but we think some kind of account creation would be required for that use case, which is something we're trying to avoid for simplicity sake.

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: LoyceV on December 29, 2022, 09:42:14 AMThey don't need a third party for that.Our goal is to simplify the process of monetizing content, and we believe https://2see.ca offers benefits for both the buyer and the seller.The seller can create the locked link, send it, and forget about it.The buyer gets faster access to the content they purchased.

comments.author: dkbit98
comments.body: Quote from: rexquigg on December 29, 2022, 12:20:32 AMOur platform is easy to use and provides a secure way for users to monetize their content and for others to access it. We hope you'll check it out and see the value it can bring to your content monetization efforts.Are you taking any percentage fee for creating this link or everything is free?Services like this could be usable if it could be used offline and if code was open source, but that is not the case with your website.Even if you don't have malicious intentions someone could hack your website and replace Bitcoin addresses with their own.

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: dkbit98 on December 29, 2022, 08:27:43 PMAre you taking any percentage fee for creating this link or everything is free?The link payment goes directly to your own address, so we operate on a pay what you want basis. You could choose to pay nothing, but we hope you choose to pay what is fair.Quote from: dkbit98 on December 29, 2022, 08:27:43 PMEven if you don't have malicious intentions someone could hack your website and replace Bitcoin addresses with their own.We take the security of our website very seriously, and we have implemented several measures to protect against unauthorized access. We understand that no system is completely immune to hacking, but we believe that the measures we have taken significantly reduce the risk of a successful attack.

comments.author: hugeblack
comments.body: What will happen if I delete cookies? What will happen if I send an amount less than the unlock value? Can I send what is left to unlock the link?I tried to create a link with the value of 1 BTC and when I clicked on the link I found the value 0.4304342 BTC.Overall, the tool would be great if you made the code open source.

comments.author: rexquigg
comments.body: Quote from: hugeblack on December 30, 2022, 02:36:19 PMWhat will happen if I delete cookies?The functionality of the site does not rely on cookies, you are free to delete them. Only the public blockchain data is referenced when unlocking a link.Quote from: hugeblack on December 30, 2022, 02:36:19 PMWhat will happen if I send an amount less than the unlock value? Can I send what is left to unlock the link?Yes, if you send less than the unlock value, the locked link will request the remaining amount to unlock the link.Quote from: hugeblack on December 30, 2022, 02:36:19 PMI tried to create a link with the value of 1 BTC and when I clicked on the link I found the value 0.4304342 BTC.If the address has been used in the past, any amount sent to the address will be considered part of the unlock amount.
